message_1:
Consider the following generating function: 

$$G(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (2x-3)^n$$

What is the coefficient of $x^{10}$ in the expansion of $G(x)$?
message_2:
The generating function $G(x)$ is a geometric series with the common ratio $(2x-3)$. We can find the sum of this geometric series using the formula:

$$G(x) = \frac{1}{1 - (2x - 3)}$$

Now, we want to find the coefficient of $x^{10}$ in the expansion of $G(x)$. To do this, we can use the binomial theorem to expand the denominator:

$$(1 - (2x - 3))^{-1} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \binom{-1}{n}(-1)^n(2x - 3)^n$$

Using the property of binomial coefficients, we have:

$$\binom{-1}{n} = (-1)^n$$

So the generating function becomes:

$$G(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (2x - 3)^n$$

Now we want to find the coefficient of $x^{10}$ in this expansion. The term $(2x - 3)^n$ will have an $x^{10}$ term when $n = 10$. So we need to find the coefficient of $x^{10}$ in $(2x - 3)^{10}$.

Using the binomial theorem again, we have:

$$(2x - 3)^{10} = \sum_{k=0}^{10} \binom{10}{k} (2x)^k (-3)^{10-k}$$

The $x^{10}$ term will be when $k = 10$:

$$\binom{10}{10} (2x)^{10} (-3)^{0} = 1 \cdot 1024x^{10} \cdot 1 = 1024x^{10}$$

So the coefficient of $x^{10}$ in the expansion of $G(x)$ is $\boxed{1024}$.
